titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Vincent Price Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:13

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, memorabilia, working scripts, writings, photographs, and published material relating to Vincent Price's acting career and activities as a supporter of the visual arts.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Vincent Price, 1992, and transferred from the Yale Film Studies Center, 1992 and 2003.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiotape, videotape, and motion picture films, as well as preservation masters and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers needing to consult the original materials should refer to the finding aid and/or a reference archivist to determine policies governing reproduction for access.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Vincent Price Papers (MS 1625). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Vincent Price was born in St. Louis, Missouri, on May 27, 1911. His father was president of the National Candy Company in St. Louis. Price received a B.A. in art history and English from Yale University in 1933, and studied art history at the University of London from 1934 to 1935. Price began his acting career in 1935 in a London stage production of Victoria Regina. He acted in Mercury Theatre productions (1937-1938), in Outward Bound (1939-1940), and in Angel Street (1941-1942). Price made his film debut in 1938 in Service de Luxe. He appeared in over one hundred films, achieving fame particularly in films of horror and suspense. In addition to his stage and film roles, Price performed on radio and television; authored several books; lectured on primitive and modern art; and served on committees and boards of arts organizations, including the Archives of American Art, U.S. Indian Arts and Crafts Board, the arts council of the University of California at Los Angeles, and the White House Fine Arts Commission. Price married three times: to Edith Barrett, Mary Grant, and Coral Browne. He had a son, Vincent Barrett Price, from his first marriage and a daughter, Victoria Price, from his second marriage. Price died in Los Angeles, California, on October 25, 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, memorabilia, working scripts, writings, photographs, and published material relating to Vincent Price's acting career and activities as a supporter of the visual arts.

The bulk ofthe collection dates from the 1940s to the 1970s, although the scrapbooks contain a great deal of material from the 1930s as well. The papers are perhaps most valuable for the ephemera they contain relating to Price's theatrical and film career. There are rare fan magazines and a number of formal and informal photographs documenting all aspects of Price's career. There is also a large amount of material that provides background information on Vincent Price's public life, including scrapbooks, clippings from newspapers and magazines, and reviews of Price's performances. In addition there is good documentation on Price's interest in and involvement with the art world.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in seven series and one addition: I. Correspondence, 1920s-1980s. II. Memorabilia, 1936-1980s. III. Publicity, 1950s-1980s. IV. Working Scripts, 1935-1990, n.d. V. Writings, 1932-1981, n.d. VI. Scrapbooks, 1910-1970s. VII. Photographs, 1890s-1980s.

controlaccess.subject: Actors -- United States
Art -- Collectors and collecting
Motion picture actors and actresses -- United States
Motion pictures
Theater
controlaccess.corpname: United States. Indian Arts and Crafts Board

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is arranged alphabetically and primarily consists of incoming letters to Price from relatives, friends, and professional colleagues. Some of the files also include clippings and memorabilia. There are many letters from Price's friend Mildred Mary Combs, playwright Laurence Housman, and various family members, especially Price's parents and his son, Vicent Barrett Price. While Price's professional film and theater career is not well documented in the correspondence, there is material from his agent W. C. Leigh and his publisher Doubleday, as well as personal correspondence with many stage and screen personalities, including Jose Ferrer, Basil Rathbone, and Helen Hayes. Price's involvement in the art world is well documented in correspondence with various artists, particularly Howard Warshaw. There are also many documents pertaining to the founding of the Los Angeles County Art Museum, and correspondence with various art dealers and museum officials. Of interest are the correspondence, office memoranda, and other materials from Price's tenure on the Indian Arts and Crafts Board of the United States Department of the Interior, which detail the Board's activities from 1957 to 1961. Additionally, some correspondence can be found in the working scripts in Series IV: Working Scripts and the pages ofthe scrapbooks in Series VI.

did.unittitle: Combs, Mildred Mary [includes correspondence, clippings and other miscellaneous material]
Fenton, Mrs. F. Reed ["Hat"; Vincent Price's sister]
Gay, Mrs. Samuel T. ["Lallie"; Vincent Prices's sister]
Leigh, W. Colston, Inc. [Vincent Price's agent]
Price, Mary Grant [Vincent Price's second wife]
United States. Department of the Interior. Indian Arts and Crafts Board

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the materials in this series derive from Price's professional acting career on stage and screen, and include film festival programs, promotional materials for films and the one-man show Diversions and Delights , theater programs, and materials from public performances by or in honor of Price. Also included are some awards and certificates as well as materials from two advertising campaigns for consumer products on which Price worked. The items in this series are arranged by type. More memorabilia, especially pertaining to theater productions, can be found in Series VI: Scrapbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two sections: Clippings and Publications. The Clippings section, arranged alphabetically by subject, consists of excerpts from mostly United States newspapers and magazines, and ranges in date from the 1960s to the 1980s. This section provides a good overview of Vincent Price's public life. For basic biographical information about Vincent Price, the "General" and "Profiles and Interviews" folders are good resources. Theater reviews are well represented, especially for Diversions and Delights, Price's one-man show about Oscar Wilde. Price's career on the lecture circuit is documented in the "Art," "Lectures," and "Villains Still Pursue Me" folders. Other clippings pertaining to his acting career and his family can be found in Series VI: Scrapbooks. The Publications section dates from the 1950s to the 1980s and is arranged alphabetically by type. The section contains movie fan magazines, privately produced fanzines, catalogs of Price's art exhibits, and books and publications about Price's film career.

Films of Vincent Price [articles, interviews, reviews, publicity]

The Films of Vincent Price by lain F. McAsh
Heroes of the Movies: Vincent Price by lain F. McAsh
Vincent Price: Actor and Art Collector by Raul Lopez and Alan Curl
American International Pictures: Twenty-five Years [catalog for retrospective]
Vincent Price Collects Drawings [catalog for exhibition; foreword and notes by Price]
II Falcone Maltese N.3 [in Italian; Price interview and filmography]
The Skull No.2: Vincent Price [in French; extensive Price filmography]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists ofthe working scripts, many annotated and autographed, used by Vincent Price for his performances on radio, television, stage, and screen, and in the recording studio. The scripts are arranged by title within each category ofperformance.

did.unittitle: Five Chelsea Lane: A Victorian Thriller in Three Acts [play by Patrick Hamilton; adapted for radio]
Charley's Aunt [by Brandon Price; two annotated copies, one belonging to Vincent Price, one to his wife Coral Browne], ca. 1962
The Cocktail Party [by T. S. Eliot]
Dial M For Murder [by Frederick Knott]
Don Juan in Hell [by George Bernard Shaw; two bound copies with annotations, and a script for the First Drama Quartet, with enclosed correspondence regarding the production]
Goodbye Again: A New Play [by Allan Scott and George Haight; with enclosures]
The Lady's Not for Burning [by Christopher Fry]
27 Wagons Full of Cotton and Other Plays [by Tennessee Williams]
Visit to a Small Planet [by Gore Vidal; with enclosures]
America the Beautiful [dramatic readings of American poetry and songs]

The Butterfly Ball and the Grasshopper's Feast [written by Alan Aldridge and William Plomer; inscribed Vincent Price Royal Albert Hall Oct 16th 1975" and "Music Roger Glover;" some reading directions and editions; names in back leaf]
D. H. Lawrence and the Women in Love [written by Guy Vaesen]
If I Forget Thee [written by Ben Aronin; typescript of dramatic reading at the Jerusalem Anniversary Dinner]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged by type, and consists ofthe plays, poetry, and other writings of Vincent Price. His early efforts at play writing are represented by manuscripts of Poet's Corner and Those Enduring Young Charms . There is also a manuscript for The Book of Joe , a memoir of his beloved dog's life.

did.unittitle: American literature lecture and Tennessee Williams reading
"The Enjoyment of Art" [lecture at Brigham Young University]
Poets Corner: A Play in Three Acts [written manuscripts and typescripts]
Art labels [catalog descriptions written by Price]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Vincent Price's scrapbooks, containing news clippings, programs, invitations, letters, and photographs, and is divided into two sections, Theater and Other. Some of the scrapbooks were disassembled for preservation purposes. Separated material is now stored in folders with each volume. Price's theater career is well documented here, especially his appearances in Victoria Regina and Diversions andDelights. There is also genealogical and biographical :material for the Price family. Similar materials can be found in Series II: Memorabilia and in the "Clippings" section of Series III: Publicity.

did.unittitle: Art exhibit [photographs with captions by Price]
Album cover with annotations and autographs
Family and early career scrapbook [contains Price family correspondence; clippings; and theater memorabilia],

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs series consists ofphotographs pertaining to Vincent Price's family, professional career, art collecting, and personal life. This collection of images sheds light on Price's personality and range of interests. The series has been divided into three sections: Vincent Price, Other individuals, and Oversize. Oversize pictures are arranged in the same order as the first two sections.

The Vincent Price section is arranged in several categories: Art collection; Portraits; Candids; Film; Interviews, speeches, public appearances; Radio; Television; and Theater. The "Portraits" files include formal posed photographs ofPrice, many made for promotional purposes as Price pursued his acting career. "Candids" are informal photographs showing Price's lighter, more casual side. The other categories document Price's work in various productions. Price's "Film" work is represented by promotional shots and film stills. Those films with an extensive number of pictures include The Abominable Dr. Phibes , House of Usher , and The Long Night . The "Theater" folders do not cover as wide a spectrum of productions as do those for his films, but they do detail Price's performances in Oliver! , Diversions and Delights , Victoria Regina , and Shoemaker's Holiday . Some examples of Price's work in other media are included in the "Radio" and "Television" folders.

The Other individuals section includes photographs of Price's first and third wives, Edith Barrett and Coral Browne, and of several generations ofthe Price family of St. Louis. The "Price Family" folders feature pictures of all sizes, ages, and subjects--from cartes de visite of Price ancestors to color prints ofPrice's daughter, Mary Victoria. There are a number of images that document Price's childhood in St. Louis and his student days at Yale. Also in this series are several pictures ofPrice's colleagues in film and the theater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Student film interview of Vincent Price discussing his days at Yale, film roles, the place of film study at Yale, concluding with a fundraising appeal to alumni to establish a tenured position in film studies.

Researchers needing to consult the original materials should refer to the finding aid and/or a reference archivist to determine policies governing reproduction for access.
